newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Europe airline 96 cargo up 4.5pct, yields down-AEA.
newsitem.headline: Europe airline 96 cargo up 4.5pct, yields down-AEA.

text.p: Total international freight carred by European carriers increased last year --but at the expense of a significant drop in yields, the Association of European Airlines (AEA) says in its 1996 yearbook

Globally, AEA airlines' freight tonne-kilometres (FTKs) increased by 4.5 percent last year on 1995 in contrast to a fall in yields of 8.8 percent in constant-dollar terms (equivalent to local currency trends), AEA added.
The FTK measurement is derived by multiplying the weight of cargo carried by the distance flown.
"The result for 1996 was that airfreight earned about $585 million less than the year before despite the traffic increase," said the report.
The outcome was that the freight contribution to total revenue declined from 15.9 percent in 1995 to 14.6 percent," it added.
In real terms, freight rates decreased about 40 percent in 10 years compared to a drop of about 30 percent for passenger fares, AEA said.
Commenting on regional trends in 1996, AEA noted that for the first time, the Far East/Australasia sector overtook the North Atlantic sector to become AEA's main freight market in FTK terms.
"Nevertheless, the United States remains by far the most important single country market on the AEA cargo network," the yearbook's report said.
